quest_title: If the vectors \(a,\, b\) and c are represented by the sides \(BC,\, CA\) and \(AB\) respectively of the \(\Delta ABC\), then
explanation_txt:
Here \({\bf a}+{\bf b}+{\bf c}={\bf 0}\).

Take cross products with \(a\):

\( b \times a + c \times a = 0 \Rightarrow a \times b = c \times a \quad \quad \dots (i) \)

Take cross products with \(b\):

\( a \times b + c \times b = 0 \Rightarrow a \times b = b \times c \quad \quad \dots (ii) \)

From (i) and (ii),

\( a \times b = b \times c = c \times a \)

quest_title: Two full turns of the circular scale of a screw gauge cover a distance of 1 mm on its main scale. The total number of divisions on circular scale is 50. Further, it is found that screw gauge has a zero error of – 0.03 mm. While measuring the diameter of a thin wire, a student notes the main scale reading of 3 mm and the number of circular scale divisions in line with the main scale as 35. The diameter of the wire is
explanation_txt:
Least count =\(\cfrac{0.5 mm}{50}=0.01mm\)

Zero error = – 0.03 mm (Given)

Measured diameter = 3 mm + 35 × 0.01 mm = 3.35 mm

Correct diameter = 3.35 – (–0.03 mm) = 3.38 mm
question_plain_title: Two full turns of the circular scale of a screw gauge cover a distance of 1 mm on its main scale. The total number of divisions on circular scale is 50. explanation_plain_text:

quest_title: A truck starts from rest with an acceleration of 1.5 m/s\({}^{2}\) while a car 150 m behind starts from rest with an acceleration 2 m/s\({}^{2}\) . The time in which car and truck become side by side is
explanation_txt:
For truck,

\(S=\cfrac{1}{2} a t^{2}=\cfrac{1.5}{2}=0.75 t^{2}\)

For car,

\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{S}+150=\cfrac{1}{2} \times 2 \mathrm{t}^{2}} \\ {0.75 \mathrm{t}^{2}+150=\mathrm{t}^{2}} \\ {150=0.25 \mathrm{t}^{2}} \\ {\mathrm{t}^{2}=\cfrac{150}{0.25}=600} \\ {\mathrm{t}=\sqrt{600}=24.5 \mathrm{sec}}\end{array}\)
question_plain_title: A truck starts from rest with an acceleration of 1.5 m/s while a car 150 m behind starts from rest with an acceleration 2 m/s . The time in which car and truck become side by side is

For car,

quest_title: A body of mass m rises to a height h = R/5 from the surface of earth of radius R. If the acceleration due to gravity on earth's surface is g then increase in PE of body is
explanation_txt:
\(\Delta \mathrm{PE}=\cfrac{-G M m}{R+\cfrac{R}{5}}+\cfrac{G M m}{R}=\cfrac{G M m}{R}\left[1-\cfrac{5}{6}\right]\)

\(\qquad =\cfrac{g R^{2} m}{R} \cfrac{1}{6}\)
\(\qquad =5 / 6 \mathrm{mgh} \quad [\because R=5h]\)

quest_title: A lens of power + 2 diopters is placed in contact with a lens of power -- 1 diopter. The combination will behave like
explanation_txt:
Combined power of the lenses,

\(P=\cfrac{1}{f} =\cfrac{1}{f_{1} } +\cfrac{1}{f_{2} } =P_{1} +P_{2} =2+(-1)=1\) diopter

\(\Rightarrow f=\cfrac{1}{P}=\cfrac{1}{1}=1 \, \textit{m}=100 \, \textit{cm}\)

\(\therefore \) A convergent lens of focal length 100 \(\textit{cm}\).
question_plain_title: A lens of power + 2 diopters is placed in contact with a lens of power -- 1 diopter. The combination will behave like
explanation_plain_text:
Combined power of the lenses,

diopter

A convergent lens of focal length 100 .
ans1_plain_text: A convergent lens of focal length 50
ans2_plain_text: A divergent lens of focal length 100
ans3_plain_text: A convergent lens of focal length 100
ans4_plain_text: A convergent lens of focal length 200

\({\cfrac{25}{\mathrm{x}^{2}}=\cfrac{100}{(2-\mathrm{x})^{2}}} \)

\( {\text { or, } 2 \mathrm{x}=2-\mathrm{x}} \)

\( {\mathrm{x}=\cfrac{2}{3} \mathrm{m}}\)

quest_title: When unpolarized light beam is incident from air onto glass (n = 1.5) at the polarizing angle
ans2_txt: Reflected and refracted beams are partially polarized
ans3_txt: The reason for (a) is that almost all the light is reflected
explanation_txt: According to Brewster’s law, when a beam of ordinary light (i.e. unpolarized) is reflected from a transparent medium (like glass), the reflected light is completely plane polarized at certain angle of incidence called the angle of polarization.
question_plain_title: When unpolarized light beam is incident from air onto glass (n = 1.5) at the polarizing angle
explanation_plain_text: According to Brewster’s law, when a beam of ordinary light (i.e. unpolarized) is reflected from a transparent medium (like glass), the reflected light is completely plane polarized at certain angle of incidence called the angle of polarization.
ans2_plain_text: Reflected and refracted beams are partially polarized
ans3_plain_text: The reason for (a) is that almost all the light is reflected

quest_title: Correct exposure for a photographic print is 10 seconds at a distance of one metre from a point source of 20 candela. For an equal fogging of the print placed at a distance of 2 m from a 16 candela source, the necessary time for exposure is
explanation_txt:
For equal fogging \(I_{2} \times t_{2} =I_{1} \times t_{1} \)

\(\Rightarrow \; \; \cfrac{L_{2} }{r_{2}^{2} } \times t_{2} =\cfrac{L_{1} }{r_{1}^{2} } \times t_{1}\)

\(\Rightarrow \; \; \cfrac{16}{4} \times t_{2} =\cfrac{20}{1} \times 10\)

\(\Rightarrow \; \; t_{2} =50\sec\)
question_plain_title: Correct exposure for a photographic print is 10 seconds at a distance of one metre from a point source of 20 candela. For an equal fogging of the print placed at a distance of 2 m from a 16 candela source, the necessary time for exposure is
explanation_plain_text: For equal fogging

ans2_txt: The statement and reason are true but the reason is not a correct explaration
ans3_txt: the statement is true but the reason is false
ans4_txt: The statement is false, through the reason is true in itself.
explanation_txt:
\(\overset{+2}Ca\,\overset{+4}C\,\overset{-6}O_3 \to \overset{+2}Ca\,\overset{-2}O+\overset{+4}C\,\overset{-4}O_2\)

Here Calcium oxide is formed, but no oxidation is talking place

quest_title: An object is placed at 22.5cm from a convex lens of focal length 15cm. In another side of object a diverging lens of focal length 30cm is placed at 15cm from convex lens & co-axially. A plane mirror is placed at 40cm from diverging lens &perpendicular to axis then the final image will be at
explanation_txt:
For convex lens

\(\mathrm{v}=\cfrac{\mathrm{fu}}{\mathrm{u}-\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{15 \times 22.5}{22.5-15}=45 \mathrm{cm}\)

For concave lens

\(\mathrm{u}=-(45-15)=-30 \mathrm{cm}\)
\(v=\infty\) i.e. light rays incident normally on mirror so image is formed with object

quest_title: 13 tanning forks are arranged in ascending order of frequency. When any two consecutive forks are sounded together the number of beats produced per sec is 2. the frequency of last fork is twice that of first. The frequency of the 10\({}^{th}\) fork is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{f}_{13}=2 \mathrm{f}_{1} \quad\) (This is same as A.P.)
\(\mathrm{N}=13\)
No. of beats \((\mathrm{m})=2\)
\(\mathrm{f}_{13}=\mathrm{f}_{1}+(13-1) \times 2\)
\(2 \mathrm{f}_{1}=\mathrm{f}_{1}+12 \times 2\)
\(\mathrm{f}_{1}=24\)
\(\mathrm{f}_{10}=\mathrm{f}_{1}+(10-1) \times 2\)
\(\quad=24+9 \times 2=42 \mathrm{Hz}\)

explanation_plain_text:

quest_title: Two fixed charges \({q}\) and \(4{q}\) are at \({r}\) distance apart. What is the position of third charge to be placed so that the system will be in equilibrium?\(
explanation_txt:
\(q \,\,\& \,\,4q\) are fixed. For equilibrium of charge \(q\) ' net force acted on \(q\,^\prime\) should be zero i.e.
\(\begin{array}{l}{\cfrac{q q^{\prime}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} x^{2}}=\cfrac{4 q q^{\prime}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}(r-x)^{2}}} \\ {\text { Or, } \cfrac{1}{x^{2}}=\cfrac{4}{(r-x)^{2}}} \\ {\text { Or, }\left(\cfrac{r-x}{x}\right)^{2}=4}\end{array}\)
Or, \(\cfrac{r-x}{x}=2\)
Or, \(\cfrac{r}{x}-1=2\)
Or, \(\cfrac{r}{x}=3\)
\(\therefore \quad x=\cfrac{r}{3}\) from \(q\)
i.e. position is \(\cfrac{r}{3}\) from \(q\) and \(r-\cfrac{r}{3}=\cfrac{2 r}{3}\) from \(4q\) .

are fixed. For equilibrium of charge ' net force acted on should be zero i.e.

from

quest_title: A finite distance separates two opposite charges having same magnitude. If \(\text{E}\) and \(\text{V}\) be the electric intensity and potential midway between them, which is true?
explanation_txt:
\(V=\cfrac{q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r}+\cfrac{(-q)}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r}=0\)

But \(E\) is vector quantity its direction is from +ve to -ve charge. Hence \(E \neq 0\) .
\(E=\cfrac{q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2}}+\cfrac{q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2}}=\cfrac{2 q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r^{2}}\) towards \(-q\)
question_plain_title: A finite distance separates two opposite charges having same magnitude. If and be the electric intensity and potential midway between them, which is true?
explanation_plain_text:
But is vector quantity its direction is from +ve to -ve charge. Hence .
towards

quest_title: For a thermocouple, the temperature of inversion is that temperature at which thermo e.m.f. is
explanation_txt:
Increasing the temperature difference between two junctions of dissimilar metals, thermo emf goes on increasing. At a particular temperature difference called neutral temperature \(T_{n}\), emf becomes maximum.

Further increase in temperature difference between junctions causes thermo emf to decrease. There exists a temperature difference at which emf falls down to zero and changes its polarity. This temperature difference is called temperature of inversion \(T_{i}\).
question_plain_title: For a thermocouple, the temperature of inversion is that temperature at which thermo e.m.f. is
explanation_plain_text:
Increasing the temperature difference between two junctions of dissimilar metals, thermo emf goes on increasing. At a particular temperature difference called neutral temperature , emf becomes maximum.

Further increase in temperature difference between junctions causes thermo emf to decrease. There exists a temperature difference at which emf falls down to zero and changes its polarity. This temperature difference is called temperature of inversion .

quest_title: When the current in a coil changes from 2 Amp to 4 Amp in 0.05 sec an e.m.f. of 8 volt is induced in the coil. The coefficient of self-inductor of the coil is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} E=L \cfrac{d i}{d t} & \Rightarrow 8=L \times\left(\cfrac{4-2}{0.05}\right) \\ & \therefore L=0.2 \text { Henry } \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: In the hydrogen spectrum \(\lambda\)\({}_{3}\) and \(\lambda\)\({}_{2}\) are the wavelengths of radiation emitted due to transition from second and first excited states to the ground state. Then the ratio \(\cfrac{\lambda_3}{\lambda_2}\) is
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{\lambda_{2}}{\lambda_{3}}=\cfrac{R\left[\cfrac{1}{1^{2}}-\cfrac{1}{3^{2}}\right]}{R\left[\cfrac{1}{1^{2}}-\cfrac{1}{2^{2}}\right]}=\cfrac{\cfrac{8}{9}}{\cfrac{3}{4}}=\cfrac{32}{27}\)
\(\therefore \cfrac{\lambda_{3}}{\lambda_{2}}=\cfrac{27}{32}\)

quest_title: 100ml 0.3N solution of NaOH was mixed with 200ml of \(\text{0.3M-H\({}_{2}\)SO\({}_{4}\)}\) solution. The normality of \(\text{H\({}_{2}\)SO\({}_{4}\)}\) in the resulting solution is;
explanation_txt:
In terms of quantity,

100 ml of 0.3N NaOH = 30 ml of 1N NaOH

200 ml of 0.3M H\(_2\)SO\(_4\) = 60 ml of 1M H\(_2\)SO\(_4\) = 120 ml of 1N H\(_2\)SO\(_4\)

In addition, amount of H\(_2\)SO\(_4\) left in the solution = 90 ml of 1N H\(_2\)SO\(_4\)

\(\therefore\) Final Concentration of H\(_2\)SO\(_4\) = \(\cfrac{0.09*1}{0.3}\) = 0.3 N
question_plain_title: 100ml 0.3N solution of NaOH was mixed with 200ml of solution. The normality of in the resulting solution is;
explanation_plain_text:
In terms of quantity,

100 ml of 0.3N NaOH = 30 ml of 1N NaOH

200 ml of 0.3M HSO = 60 ml of 1M HSO = 120 ml of 1N HSO

In addition, amount of HSO left in the solution = 90 ml of 1N HSO

Final Concentration of HSO = = 0.3 N

quest_title: If \(\alpha \) and \(\beta \) are the roots of the equation \(4x^{2} +3x+7=0\), then \(\cfrac{1}{\alpha } +\cfrac{1}{\beta } \)=
explanation_txt:
Given equation \(4x^{2} +3x+7=0\),

therefore \(\alpha +\beta =-\cfrac{3}{4} \) and \(\alpha \beta =\cfrac{7}{4} \)

Now :

\(\cfrac{1}{\alpha } +\cfrac{1}{\beta } =\cfrac{\alpha +\beta }{\alpha \beta } =\cfrac{-3/4}{7/4} =\cfrac{-3}{4} \times \cfrac{4}{7} =-\cfrac{3}{7} \).

quest_title: \(\tan (\cos ^{-1} x)\) is equal to
explanation_txt:
Let \(\cos ^{-1} x=\theta .\)

Then \(x=\cos \theta \)

\[\Rightarrow \, \, \tan \theta =\sqrt{\sec ^{2} \theta -1} =\sqrt{\cfrac{1}{x^{2} } -1} =\sqrt{\cfrac{1-x^{2} }{x} } \]

\[{\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} \, \, \tan \, (\cos ^{-1} x)=\tan \theta =\cfrac{\sqrt{1-x^{2} } }{x} . \]

explanation_txt:

quest_title: If the position vectors of the point A, B, C be i, j, k respectively and P be a point such that \(\vec { A B } = \vec { C P }\) then the position vector of P is
explanation_txt:
Let the position vector of P is \(x \mathbf { i } + y \mathbf { j } + z \mathbf { k }\) then

\( \vec { A B } = \vec { C P } \Rightarrow \mathbf { j } - \mathbf { i } = x \mathbf { i } + y \mathbf { j } + ( z - 1 ) \mathbf { k } \)

By comparing the coefficients of i, j and k we get

\(x = - 1 , \quad y = 1 \) and \( z - 1 = 0 \Rightarrow z = 1 \)

Hence required position vector is \(- \mathbf { i } + \mathbf { j } + \mathbf { k }\)

quest_title: A unit vector perpendicular to the plane determined by the points (1, – 1, 2), (2, 0, – 1) and (0, 2, 1) is
explanation_txt:
\( \mathbf { a } = \mathbf { i } + \mathbf { j } - 3 \mathbf { k } , \quad \mathbf { b } = - 2 \mathbf { i } + 2 \mathbf { j } + 2 \mathbf { k } \)

\( \mathbf { a } \times \mathbf { b } = \left| \begin{array} { c c c } { \mathbf { i } } & { \mathbf { j } } & { \mathbf { k } } \\ { 1 } & { 1 } & { - 3 } \\ { - 2 } & { 2 } & { 2 } \end{array} \right| = 8 \mathbf { i } + 4 \mathbf { j } + 4 \mathbf { k } \)

Hence the required unit vector is \( \pm \cfrac { 2 \mathbf { i } + \mathbf { j } + \mathbf { k } } { \sqrt { 6 } } \)

quest_title: A particle of mass m is rotating along a circular path of radius r. Its angular momentum is L. The centripetal force acting on particle is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{L}=\mathrm{mvr} \quad \therefore \mathrm{v}=\cfrac{L}{m r}\)

\(\therefore\) Centripetal force \((\mathrm{F})=\cfrac{m v^{2}}{r}\)

\(\qquad=\cfrac{m L^{2}}{m^{2} r^{2} r}=\cfrac{L^{2}}{m r^{3}}\)
question_plain_title: A particle of mass m is rotating along a circular path of radius r. Its angular momentum is L. The centripetal force acting on particle is
explanation_plain_text: Centripetal force

quest_title: A mass m is attached with two identical spring as shown in fig. has frequency 'f'. If one of the spring is removed then frequency will be
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{eg}}=2 \mathrm{k}\)
\(\mathrm{f}=\cfrac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\cfrac{2 k}{m}}\)........(i)

For single,

\(\mathrm{f}=\cfrac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\cfrac{k}{m}}\) ..........(ii)

From (i) and (ii),

\(\therefore \cfrac{f^{\prime}}{f}=\sqrt{\cfrac{1}{2}}\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{f}=\cfrac{f}{\sqrt{2}}\)
